natural problem: Simplify the following: $(2y-1)\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7).$  Express your answer as a polynomial with the degrees of the terms in decreasing order.

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify the following: $(2y-1)\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7).$  Express your answer as a polynomial with the degrees of the terms in decreasing order. The final Answer is 8y^{11}+6y^9-2y^7
 ### Proof
 We distribute and simplify: \begin{align} & (2y-1)\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)\\ =& 2y\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)-(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)\\ =& 8y^{11}+4y^{10}+8y^9+4y^8\\ &-4y^{10}-2y^9-4y^8-2y^7. \end{align}We are left with $\boxed{8y^{11}+6y^9-2y^7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes y :: real
shows  "(2*y - 1) * (4*y^10 + 2*y^9 + 4*y^8 + 2*y^7) = 8*y^11 + 4*y^10 - 2*y^7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Multiply the binomial $(2y - 1)$ by the polynomial $(4y^{10} + 2y^{9} + 4y^{8} + 2y^{7})$ and simplify the result. The final answer is $8y^{11} + 4y^{10} - 2y^{7}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> y. P y = 2 * y - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. Q y = 4 * y powr 10 + 2 * y powr 9 + 4 * y powr 8 + 2 * y powr 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> y. P y * Q y = R y"
shows  "R y = 8 * y powr 11 + 4 * y powr 10 - 2 * y powr 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify the following: $(2y-1)\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7).$  Express your answer as a polynomial with the degrees of the terms in decreasing order. The final Answer is 8y^{11}+6y^9-2y^7
 ### Proof
 We distribute and simplify: \begin{align} & (2y-1)\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)\\ =& 2y\cdot(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)-(4y^{10}+2y^9+4y^8+2y^7)\\ =& 8y^{11}+4y^{10}+8y^9+4y^8\\ &-4y^{10}-2y^9-4y^8-2y^7. \end{align}We are left with $\boxed{8y^{11}+6y^9-2y^7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> y. P y = 2 * y - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. Q y = 4 * y powr 10 + 2 * y powr 9 + 4 * y powr 8 + 2 * y powr 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> y. P y * Q y = R y"
shows  "R y = 8 * y powr 11 + 4 * y powr 10 - 2 * y powr 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two functions $P(y) = 2y - 1$ and $Q(y) = 4y^{10} + 2y^{9} + 4y^{8} + 2y^{7}$, find the function $R(y)$ that is the product of $P(y)$ and $Q(y)$. The final answer is $R(y) = 8y^{11} + 4y^{10} - 2y^{7}$.
